content:
ICYMI: Must-watch panel @ColumbiaDEFRAG  on WarGames (1983) with an absolutely amazing panel @CISAJen, @LanceWeiler, Maj. Gen. Kevin Huyck (@USNorthernCmd), @webjedi, @MattDevost

https://t.co/DiyttX8iI6

Good article @MarkAPomerleau on latest AF organizational advancement/confusion on cyber

The latest step of 25+ years of "what is cyber" & trying to "normalize"  w/in AF

Compare w/my history from 2019 in @ASForcesMag 

https://t.co/0LeFTZQyaa

https://t.co/D4b1FG6C4l

Tremendous thanks to Ann of Microsoft for this engaging discussion, now out on the Afternoon Cyber Tea podcast...

https://t.co/8AKrQh4Iuy https://t.co/rGjFxvLDFX

Thanks for having me on the show @securityweekly!

Great discussion on "are we winning?" and indicators if cyberspace is indeed becoming more defensible, as called for by @ONCD  

https://t.co/TmgBx0aDSr

Cyber Resilience & Collaboration, our new exec ed course, 7 to 9 June, here @Columbia

Led by @GregRattray_  & me, this course is for private & public sector cyber leaders, military, & govt officials

Deep dives on cyber risks, governance, & collaboration

https://t.co/HERSiATKgE

The MattGPT by @MattDevost "trained on Matt's writing, interviews, and over 1000 hand-curated reference documents" is totally worth the time to try...

https://t.co/toxCUR1H2H

https://t.co/XpHW5OEJJ5 https://t.co/ZxRP8TaBbI

Nat-sec impact of Change Healthcare disruption are pretty stunning

NSC deputies committee has been meeting DAILY, according to @johnnysaks130 

All from one ransomware attack at a single point of failure... 

https://t.co/9h5TwIdsNH

Gonna keep saying it every time I read it. 

The @JonKBateman report @CNASdc on Russia's wartime use of cyber in Ukraine is a really rewarding and balanced piece...

https://t.co/u0W41ka4AI

Epic event of Future of Ukraine, @ColumbiaIGP @ColumbiaSIPA 

With @HillaryClinton @ianbremmer @KimberlyMarten Amb Yovanovich, Amb Markarova, @VelshiMSNBC @YarhiMilo, & many more!

7 February, noon to 2:30pm

https://t.co/u1lkrS1cP5

The Samantha Jennings-Jones Memorial Scholarship is now open for applications.

Sam was a treasured colleague at @ONCD and we all hope her legacy will continue.

https://t.co/dUpQ3KnXn1

Didn't understand the @craignewmark fascination with pigeons until a small flock of seven (these three plus another four behind, on the sill) decided to come visit us each night to bed down...

Craig: we get it now! https://t.co/6FdEr03pUM

Thanks to @maurertim for stopping by @ColumbiaSIPA to speak with students about his incredible journey, careers in cyber, and of course working in the NSC on democracy and technology!

ICYMI here's some of the amazing work he did there:
https://t.co/hfupRBENEp https://t.co/p0eJyWkcpf

In remembrance of Steve Katz, the world's first CISO...

I got to know Steve in 2001, only a few years after he started his role at Citi. Many of us got to hear him recount that early history at a dinner marking the 20th anniversary of the FS-ISAC 

https://t.co/xtAQqPvqse

Apply now to be a postdoc research scholar at Saltzman Institute of War & Peace Studies @ColumbiaSIPA!!!

https://t.co/mcMUpmIViT

Not to one-up the beautiful, sunny landscapes photos which @johnmccumber and @MerrittBaer take of the view from their windows...

But here in NYC, we get crews filming naked dudes throwing away stuff https://t.co/qcfQxfhqXh

Applications open for Hinman fellows @SilveradoPolicy "for graduate students ... pursuing public policy careers ... who would not otherwise have the financial means to spend a summer" in DC

Get to work & learn w/ the great @Eco2Sec & @DAlperovitch!

https://t.co/YgbCvChLel

The National Cybersecurity Strategy calls for cyber regulation

But the terms are confusing .... What do we mean by performance-based or principles-based regulation?

A thread, based on my recent piece @lawfare to make sense of it all

https://t.co/b2xKcYq0Zh

New report from New York Cyber Task Force @ColumbiaSIPA comes out tonight!

https://t.co/LzEppFPsGw

New job for a program and management analyst at National Risk Management Center @CISAgov 

It's GS-13 ($112k to $145k) to suitable for grad students re-entering the works force!

https://t.co/qFWpXa49t3

Apply soon for this GS-13 job @CISAgov National Risk Management Center! 

Working in the Chief of Staff's office, you'll learn everything about the mission of NRMC...

https://t.co/q4e6ppUBTS

Honored to join @DAlperovitch  being awarded the Outstanding American by Choice to recognize achievements of naturalized U.S. citizens, presented by Secretary Mayorkas, himself a naturalized American 

Congrats to Dmitri, @Eco2Sec, & whole team at @SilveradoPolicy & @alperovitch https://t.co/z1yrYt1kNS

OH at Air Force-Navy tailgate:

"I became a SEAL to serve the country, shoot guns, and blow stuff up. Then I encountered DTS..."

Want to help secure America's elections? 

New job posting @CISAgov to lead the Election Infrastructure Subsector Risk Management Agency!

Job closes tomorrow though!

https://t.co/hLspNoWqxx

Articles on AI cybersecurity are often just opinion pieces arguing an "arms race" or benefit to either defenders or attackers 

My new @ASPI_CTS  article more comprehensively analyzes AI's advantages to defense & offense using NIST CSF & Cyber Kill Chain

https://t.co/Q1KU7aGEW3

Infosec twitter can miss a lot of OT, like this interesting story on fire alarms moving to the cloud 

Mostly covers benefits, but a bit on security. Wish it'd mentioned DDoS impact, but still worthwhile read

https://t.co/UvmVCiKiza

Incredible role @ColumbiaSIPA open now for practitioner-academics  to be the Shelby Cullom Davis Professor to teach international diplomacy and US Foreign Policy & direct the storied International Fellows Program

https://t.co/KyvlZXT8a7
So, does your neighborhood also get topped up with liquid nitrogen? https://t.co/i7x1nWo5U9

Great insights from Ukraine’s energy minister @TheEconomist -- cyber is a worse threat than kinetic b/c it can paralyze the whole system, not just individual parts

https://t.co/hYGvv3WwkN https://t.co/3k4AdOEUSh

If you haven't read "You'll See This Message When It Is Too Late," really recommend it for policy, economic, and legal insights to fix cybersecurity at scale

@josephinecwolff did a great job with it and thrilled to say we've added it to the syllabus here at @ColumbiaSIPA! https://t.co/CYdQNm4PUJ

New jobs at National Risk Management Center @CISAgov!

GS 13-14 for a data scientist: https://t.co/kB02eeQIau

GS 12-13 admin officer in the Chief of Staff's office: https://t.co/l0pOoLhKFO

Excited for first course co-teaching w/ Evan Wolff @Crowell_Moring & Charles Carmakal @Mandiant 

Just one of the exciting cyber courses here @ColumbiaSIPA! https://t.co/UYjzgILeQb

Great opening @CISACyber National Cyber Risk Management Center  for a direct-hire GS 9 through 12 to perform risk assessments, develop cyber risk indicators

Closes 5 September so apply quickly!

https://t.co/wyQITDj2mY

Wargames is @KembaWalden46's fave hacker flick! 

Yours too? 

Check out this amazing event @ColumbiaSIPA talking Wargames with @CISAJen, @webjedi, @MattDevost, and Maj Gen Kevin Huyck, then head of ops (J3) for NORAD!

https://t.co/DiyttX8QxE

So cool...

Hey grads and students interested in #infosecjobs check out this open opportunity for internships (unpaid, boo) at State Department's office of Cyberspace & Digital Policy! 

https://t.co/4cAVoyeBPg

Calling all (senior) analysts!

NRMC advertising for a senior-executive Associate Director for Analytic Capabilities to join @cisa

https://t.co/eWR1DQUJjH
Been in a great streak with Wordle lately... https://t.co/PHfBEnU2v8

JOB!

This GS-13 communications analyst position in NRMC @CISAgov is a good fit for a recent graduate! 

You'd be helping NRMC leadership on speeches, presentations. Good way to learn a range of topics & get your foot in the door

https://t.co/kQeT3YBQvE

Sweet! @CUNY advertising for an Assistant Professor of Policy Cyber Security

https://t.co/UXnoQBm1dL

Multiple GS-15 branch chief vacancies at @CISAgov National Risk Management Center! 

Risk Prioritization
Solutions Engineering
Emerging Risks
Initiatives
Critical Infrastructure

Hurry, this closes TODAY!

https://t.co/Loe3d8hJDM

"In Mr Putin’s world, powerful leaders do not let people off and they do not ask for help from the junior dictator next door."

The meaning of Prigozhin’s short-lived mutiny from TheEconomist https://t.co/9jyPoPgqEp

Oooga! Oooga!

Love intelligence? Love history? 

Maybe you'd love being a historian @NSAGov? Of course you would!

https://t.co/4xMER7zDcf

Congrats to the new Catherine Hinman Memorial Fellows!

And thanks to @Eco2Sec @DAlperovitch and the whole @SilveradoPolicy team for this great initiative

https://t.co/rOBINFDOvB

New article up at The Lawfare Institute on 25 years of White House cyber policies. This is part 1 of 2, with another coming out next week.

Twenty-five years ago, on May 22, 1998, the Clinton administration published the White Hous…https://t.co/fegvA2Zfsw https://t.co/VU0y6uEPQt

Really looking forward to reading this economics article on cyber impact on state & local governments

Like others from these authors, they have access to unique data sets (like government financing costs) for interesting insights

https://t.co/hCcu1gee2k https://t.co/1h5soc5OmU

First batch of briefings just dropped @BlackHatEvents!

Excited to be on the review board for my third year...

https://t.co/xIMrywXYEj

NRMC using it's direct hire authority @CISACyber to bring on GS-13s and GS-14s with cyber/IT background ($112,015 - $172,075)

Cyber-related policy, research, analysis, and project management

Apply now to join the great team at NRMC!

https://t.co/npJPXaxyQD

The military role in the 1980’s “war on drugs” was challenging. Just read “Sum of All Fears” to get a sense.

Here’s the path to some POTUS ordering USCYBER against Mexican drug cartels:

Exceptional interview @bgroothuis at @TheRecord_Media @AlexMartin! Has it all: subject matter knowledge, process, details, and unique insights. 

Thanks to @josephmenn for the tip in the WaPo Cyber 202

https://t.co/1IEGjGMszS

So for those following defacements and info ops:

If you were coding a database including war-related Russia or Ukraine webpage defacements ...

(a) Default assumption each defacement is an cyber-enabled info op OR

(b) Default assumption defacement is mere nuisance?
Curious how Texeira got so much varied material, whether it was through hunting, gathering, or salvaging?

Coolest job I've posted in ages! 

Who'd like to be a historian at US Cyber Command!

Work with Michael Warner, the command historian to help document the history of cyber conflict and the command. We must professionalize the study…https://t.co/7dXwgIwvj6 https://t.co/X31am0iPXP

Coolest job I've posted in ages!

Historian at @US_CYBERCOM !!! 

Work with Michael Warner, the command historian to help document the history of cyber conflict and the command

https://t.co/XbIN98wG44 https://t.co/UtZjqoLSQ5

Problem: "missingness" of cyber data on cyber & international relations 

One solution: Literature from financial stability. Papers by economists from the Fed system look at likelihood, impact of major cyber incidents
Scholarships for the Intelligence and National Security Foundation (INSF) ... deadline coming up on 14 April! https://t.co/ZtuTV2kA2G
Want to learn more about ICANN or DNS and how the Internet really works? Check out this ICANN 101 webinars... https://t.co/81BaDelbzh

Want to learn more about ICANN or DNS and how the Internet really works? Check out this ICANN 101 webinars...

https://t.co/mqAW7nxUl3

Scholarships for the Intelligence and National Security Foundation (INSF) ... deadline coming up on 14 April!

https://t.co/frBv6c3tr1

Please join in person @ColumbiaSIPA or online for 14 April conference on cyber risk to financial stability, in partnership w/ @NewYorkFed 

SIPA produced much of the initial research on this important field, like the general framework, below...

https://t.co/pukSgHAHYw https://t.co/6CPKaR44qg

My new piece up at @CFR_org 

Assessments of Russian cyber attacks re Ukraine capabilities have missed a crucial lesson from fifteen years ago: cyber power requires soft power

https://t.co/x9BUvrXBnB

My new piece on #cyber power and #ukrainerussiawar at Council on Foreign Relations.

Cyber experts, policymakers, and practitioners are striving to understand how cyber capabilities have been used since the Russian invasion of Ukra…https://t.co/jiNXBnoT9N https://t.co/rp91gTJN8B

Do you still use cyber in wartime if you can physically destroy a target?

Senior DoD official in @MorningCybersec says yes, of course, cc @johnnysaks130

Many scholars take opposite view: why both using cyber once bombs start flying

https://t.co/NGDL7WoSkr https://t.co/xvdxxMrJw6

Please join the Columbia | SIPA and Federal Reserve Bank of New York for our Fourth Annual State-of-the-Field Conference on Cyber Risk to Financial Stability on 14 April 2023!

This is the major global conference on how cyber risks…https://t.co/xLQyTTvyiB https://t.co/8z63H4mzkk

Very cool jobs @CISAgov NRMC!

GS-2210-15 IT Cybersecurity Specialist; closes 3/30/2023 (Hiring Manager: AD Harrington) 

https://t.co/UL5LTCeluE

ICYMI, we just passed the 25th anniversary of SOLAR SUNRISE, the first major named cyber campaign, and one of the most consequential ever! 

It was the first to lead to a coordinated US government response by the FBI (and its new N…https://t.co/SPWCxqh13D https://t.co/JRsSggaSPf

Cyber threat #intelligence has a longer history than many realize. 

Twenty years ago, I built this #CTI indications and warning matrix for Goldman Sachs and larger FS-ISAC on whether the upcoming US invasion of Iraq would be likely to lead to major #cybe…https://t.co/zcAAIN1Epv

Such a mismatch between the consensus view of the entire Intelligence Community (per the ATA) and international-relations academics, many of whom don't believe cyber capabilities can be escalatory or particularly effective in wartime

https://t.co/CEmHMOtWMW https://t.co/jkn8LE3Wm3

Really humbling to have my thoughts on "Russia and Ukraine, One Year Later" listed along these amazing scholars...

https://t.co/0g0qJrJx1W https://t.co/zZOLvbMKEj

This quote from @jonrlindsay was about naval & land combat, but has major implications for cyber as well.

Missed shots still land somewhere and they change the political makeup of cyber conflict...

From Information Technology and Military Power: https://t.co/v8mKGv7SXU https://t.co/TTys18kQHM

Great Cybersecurity 202 followup about @CISAJen @CISACyber on “secure-by-design” (by @timstarks)

**Insecurity by design is a 50-year old problem.** Excerpt below from Andersen report of 1972

Glad CISA is taking this on!

https://t.co/bfo3fdWUAT https://t.co/2MbZijKIKs
Not a funny take on #chinaspyballoon but remember that overflying denied airspace was pretty much the primary original mission of the U-2 and SR-71...

Right that @CISACyber @CISAJen want to hold companies responsible for cybersecurity

One way to scale this policy, as I wrote in 2014, is to convince key, activist shareholders -- Warren Buffett, CalPers -- to vote their shares to improve security

https://t.co/c0HShh9lCX

Software liability is center of attention, so definitely study Jane Chong's series @lawfareblog in 2013 (tipped by @RosenzweigP) 

Especially if you compare software to auto safety, it's a must read!

https://t.co/irlhCP12TX
I have questions... https://t.co/bxbrGQs7jX

Looking forward to reading "TikTok v. Trump and the Uncertain Future of National Security-based Restrictions on Data Trade" on gaps in US toolboc

I’ve struggled a bit since data can be simply bought, so what threat is there in just the flag of ownership? 
https://t.co/4tSvvHFFq0

Reworking my syllabus on "Foundations of Cyber Conflict" and  @peterwsinger @allanfriedman still is a unique book on so many basics!

Would love an updated version!

https://t.co/U3KSFwu1m4

CUNY Baruch College looking for tenure track professor, with a specialization in international cybersecurity and global security!

Thanks to @adschina for the tip...

https://t.co/aId0RI3q5L
Just got a major article rejected by a journal. Sigh. Happens to everyone! Don't let it get you down!

ICYMI: Alex Klimberg has a great article "Of Ships and Cyber: Transposing the Incidents at Sea Agreement" for @CSIS_Tech 

Lots of past work on INCSEA on cyber but Alex goes article by article to better develop the idea

https://t.co/Iqnncmh7v9

Sweet tenure-track job at @UofNH for an assistant or associate professor of intelligence studies! 

cc @karlgrindal 

https://t.co/0LhS812eHP

Reupping this really important piece @johnnysaks130 @MorningCybersec @NSA_CSDirector 

Better title might've been "NSA cyber director: fight against ransomware shows limits of counteroffensive 'defending forward'" 

https://t.co/8vrh8w9jFJ

Not an argument used much before or since.

In 2015, Admiral Rogers testified that just as building the triad w/ "robust" C2 helped nuclear stability, nations building major cyber commands would be ultimately stabilizing 

https://t.co/0F3gsK5RcC https://t.co/zlsvqFLILy

Major respect for mainland Chinese students here @Columbia for standing against the Communist Party

Big gathering last night... https://t.co/TzObzzQav9

Sen Romney: "only effective way to stop [cyber attacks] is to attack back ... the best defense is a good offense"

It's been 1739 days since @US_CYBERCOM announced "defend forward." Time for DoD to produce unclas evidence that offense is a good defense

https://t.co/QbimPBmqoD

Great point on escalation @MorningCybersec @johnnysaks130 

@NSA_CSDirector sees "decline" “in [adversary] willingness to use large-scale vulnerabilities” like NotPetya, WannaCry

(1) Possible taboo against them & (2) harder now, as need to chain exploits
https://t.co/8vrh8w9jFJ

Interested in the cyber parallels of this piece by @Mipeck1: 

"Initially, Russia's jamming offensive was devastating ... [but doomed by] poor planning, lack of coordination, & general indifference by Russian commanders toward getting the details right" 

https://t.co/WDPdbHmXR1

Such a mismatch:

International relations theorists: ransomware is not much a natsec threat

Reality: Over half of UK COBRA meetings are on ransomware. Not half of all *cyber* meetings, half of ALL 

https://t.co/ErNFrTyTsv

The completely unchoreographed, candid poses of Michael Novak (artistic director @paultaylordance) & Steve Biddle (@SIWPSColumbia) while discussing themes of war in the arts, after performance of stunning anti-war ballet, The Green Table (Kurt Joos, 1932) https://t.co/MsbqeTM57d

Great open position for risk management at National Risk Management Center @CISAgov 

Now open for GS-14!

https://t.co/aaJCPOEyBc
Wrote this in 2014. Still true? https://t.co/puUntI2Dde

Totally loving/borrowing this quote from @woodyatpch. Just strikes so many great notes: 

"To the degree that I’ve learned about cybersecurity, it’s because I started when it was simple and I’ve never really looked away"

Worth reading the full interview!

https://t.co/qT0B1P0HI3

Have or getting a Ph.D. in Political Science, Public Policy, or a cyber-related field? 

Come join us at @ColumbiaSIPA as a tenure-track assistant professor!

https://t.co/xba0oDlT07
Hey all, if you following @ncdinglis for news on national cyber, be sure to also check out @KembaWalden46, the principal deputy ONCD!
Google may not know me as well as it thinks... https://t.co/a0Z8FAI0e6

"Bob Jervis made important contributions to research on cyber conflict because he knew that, although it was fought using new kinds of tools, it was still conflict"

Honored to share reminiscences & contributions from Bob @SIWPSColumbia 

https://t.co/HWgs9FsHrN

Honored to be on the list of Cybersecurity Visionaries for the CyberScoop 50 Awards @CyberScoopNews 

https://t.co/xJjeau5GZ9

Another great poli-sci tenure-line position, @AmericanU with the brilliant @JoshRovner1 

Only a few years ago, PhDs were getting advice to avoid cyber until after they'd secured tenure. The field changed so fast!

https://t.co/FnvJhZOwtr

How are you de-toxing and catching up on email post BH and DC?

Me: @RiversideParkNY https://t.co/AyRL53LzRU

Because in NYC, you can just walk down the street and hear Nathan and the Zydeco Cha Chas ...

@LincolnCenter Oasis https://t.co/drGcjJlnby
Beautiful Manhattan sunset... https://t.co/fRHU50pMBv

One reason to study cyber at @ColumbiaSIPA: the amazing connections between students & alumni! 

Just completed summer DC trip w/ 18 students, recent alum, & even a just-admitted student to talk careers with alumni & others around DC

Check out this awesome group! https://t.co/dImwXW5QFl
Seventeen years after I last worked here, happy to be back at the White House, on part-time detail from @CISAgov, to help @ONCD draft the nation's next cyber strategy. https://t.co/qYNCeP4OZP

Just finished a debate @eborghard @CFR_org where we agreed the difficulty using cyber against weapon systems in wartime, esp at scale

Plausible counterexample: RU or UA find an 0day for DJI drones, patch their own, then disable or commandeer all drones of the other side

What an out-of-date practice question for a cert: 

'The President's Critical Infrastructure Protection Board's "National Strategy to Secure Cyberspace" report outlines which of the following?'

That strategy was from 2003 ... https://t.co/qrsptNhXgd

More important than what USCYBER meant saying "we've done offense against Russia on behalf of the Ukrainians" is what Russia heard

They probably know about it & don't care about the words

They just *might* care deeply. Just imagine GRU machismo & response to status challenge

@GlitchyMichael Great clarification!

Even it were only hunt forward, if Russian military teams were encountering US military teams during a conventional invasion, their military (and political) reaction may be substantially different than peacetime
@GlitchyMichael True, but Nakasone did say in regard to Ukraine: "We've conducted a series of operations across the full spectrum; offensive, defensive, [and] information operations."

Conti's ransomware assault on Costa Rica should be mandatory case study on offensive cyber coercion

If a small state can be bullied for ransom (even if they're resisting) another might be bullied to, say, veto more sanctions on Russian or shun Taiwan

https://t.co/ussCKdWDcP
If you have to try to finish a paper I'm NYC on a Friday afternoon, there are worse ways... https://t.co/XXXvY3A3vs

Sweet job opening at @CISAgov in the National Risk Management Center for a GS-14 supervisory analyst to "identify cyber/physical infrastructure threats and risks"

https://t.co/u8DvdppXIR

Love this assessment by @maddiestone in today's WaPo Cyber 202 by @Joseph_Marks_ : "58 zero days [is] less than 20% of the total number ... exploited in 2021"

https://t.co/momlT3ZIAv
@carryingthegun Thanks CtG!

DoD has advanced capabilities but cannot fix the internet at scale (as does Microsoft, Google), directly thwart adversaries at scale (CrowdStrike, Mandiant), share intel at scale (@CyberAlliance), or reinforce core infrastructure during attacks at scale (Cloudflare, Verizon)

Inspired by Dick Betts @SIWPSColumbia, my latest at @lawfareblog: "Soldiers, Statesmen and Cyber Crises: Cyberspace and Civil-Military Relations"

[Sorry for the gendered language, but it is a reference to Dick's classic book]

https://t.co/6ZsquiOCvD

Cyber is weird reason #3,428

In the Cold War, we mostly knew what NATO was developing, deploying, and operating but USSR was a closed book

In cyber conflict, other than broad force structure, we know far more about what adversary government APTs are up to than our own

Scary paragraph (and article) by George Beebe @CFTNI 

https://t.co/E3qjtq5VJn https://t.co/oHyAOy3OWs
Not comforting that Putin's own generals probably don't know if he's serious about tactical nuclear weapons either...

Thanks to the amazing @JordanKlara  @CyberpeaceInst for joining our class on cyber conflict @ColumbiaSIPA! 

We've focused the class squarely on Ukraine & Klara discussed the basics of CPI, how civilians are affected by cyber conflict, & intl law! https://t.co/cci3uvPznK

Made a for of a bottle of Johnny Blue w/ Stuart Gottlieb @SIWPSColumbia yesterday on the persistence of sanctions:

By March 2026, is NordStream 2

More realistic to me isn't a no-fly zone, but a Kyiv Airlift, of aircraft bringing food & humanitarian supplies to the capitol, if it gets surrounded

Might be pressure for such an airlift ... and for those aircraft to have NATO fighter & SEAD escort

Why no major Russia cyber onslaught? Here’s a thread on various reasons we’ve heard

Not sure if this list by @VirpratapVS  & me improves on the four in excellent article @ciaranmartinoxf  (ease, effectiveness, escalation, ethics) but just in case...

https://t.co/od3ikrWt1G

US won't help Ukraine w/ boots on the ground or no-fly zone for direct combat with Russia

But assistance w/cyber capabilities maybe more tempting:
- Disrupt Russian military C2 in Ukraine?
- Determine OOB, locations to pass to Ukraine?
- Target conscripts, commanders w/messages?

Less reflexively against this Ukraine outsourcing hacking than others but...

This is an incredibly dangerous moment for Europe. De-escalation and peace will be hard enough on their own without outsourced hacking to worry about.

A country under threat of military invasion is getting DDoSed

They're victims, defenders who could be doing a lot of other things, suffering yet again

Missing time w/ their families, struggling w/out enough resources, yet again

STFU if this isn't serious enough attack for you
Thanks to @DAlperovitch for visiting my class on cyber conflict @ColumbiaSIPA to talk Ukraine, cyber conflict, and cyber threat intelligence! https://t.co/gzLLdSKIaf

OTD in 1998: SOLAR SUNRISE began. AFCERT detected major intrusions seeming tracing in part to the Middle East during a major buildup against Saddam Hussein's Iraq.

DEPSECDEF briefed POTUS this might be a digital Pearl Harbor. It was Makaveli and Stimpy, 2 teens from California

Thinking on defending forward and persistent engagement has advanced since my "memo to POTUS" of May 2018. Still pretty much stand by my assessment & recommendations for the NSC 

https://t.co/dmoHGJibh9 https://t.co/Jqv5PJPNY0
Sorry to hear @BobKolasky is leaving NRMC ... but excited to see what his experience and insight will bring to the risk-management industry!

Hope @FSISAC, ARC watching Ukraine

Putin couldn't use cyber to disrupt Western finance b/c of RU dependence

That restraint weakens if US sanctions cut RU off from SWIFT & the international dollar economy

If RU can't play the game, little to lose from just flipping the table

Theories on cyber dynamics - esp escalation - MUST incorporate how leaders & practitioners actually think & respond

Some leaders (Nakasone) less aggressive than others: then-deputy commander USCYBER: "we cannot .. cede any territory to these adversaries"
https://t.co/lM5rA92x3y https://t.co/IlKLTiTFJn
Anyone in twitterland used to work at NORAD, especially in cyber defense?

There's seeming consensus states can't brandish cyber capabilities. Once you reveal your capability, it becomes powerless 

But (1) if your adversary can do it once, decisionmakers will reasonably fear they can do it again

And (2) in IRL brandishing power decreases gradually

Does offense have the advantage over defense in cyberspace? 

We talk past each other as the question is actually "under what conditions?" one may have the advantage

New piece @lawfareblog describes 5 different perspectives for cyber o-d comparisons 

https://t.co/jucwoLyBhb

All these things can be true at once:
1) Solar Winds was espionage not an attack or act of war
2) US has done extensive cyber espionage & was predator long before it was prey

Interesting point from @Jenn_Genn: 

Did SVR have a plan for what happened after Solar Winds got discovered?

Or were they like US after Stuxnet & Snowden revelations and appeared to be winging it?

Imagine how much better off we'd been in Solar Winds response w/ @TomBossert @RGB_Lights @C_C_Krebs at the helm ... or at least if they'd been backfilled by a competent team (or even replaced at all)

The utter incomprehensible incompetence of it all...

Further two cents: When we learn classified US networks are "affected" by Solar Winds incident, don't go apeshit. That doesn't mean they were actively exploited!

Even if those networks used Orion, Russians likely would have difficult time exploiting any initial access

The deterrence question vexing me isn't "how could we deter Russia from spying?" Agree w/ @JoshRovner1 et al  that hard to deter espionage

Worth asking "how might Russia have used their SolarWinds access to deter the US, change our decision calculus?"

3 separate framing for SolarWinds:

1) Russia: how to retaliate/dissuade is natsec question
2) Remediate: who is affected, overall impact, & how to remediate is 1st order infosec qs
3) Respond: how to better protect, what to do about supply chain, etc all 2nd order infosec qs
@donachaidh Thanks for the correction! Maybe "getting investigation sensitive" info is the right example then?
@donachaidh Not leaking them, using them to know what USG knows and how to avoid them. And really just an example of what Russia might be able to get off of unclassified networks
